contextId.occurrenceNote: The "advice of the wicked" is spoken of as if it were a path to follow. Alternate translation: "who does not follow the advice of the wicked" or "who does not do what wicked people advise" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who does not walk in the advice of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the word "pathway" represents the way people live. The word "stand" is in parallel with "walk." Alternate translation: "imitate the behavior of sinful people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: stand in the pathway with sinners

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) not standing in the judgment is a metonym for being judged by God and having to leave his presence. Alternate translation: "will not continue to stay before God when he judges them" or "will have to leave God's presence when he judges them as guilty" or 2) not standing in the judgment is a metaphor for being condemned in the judgment. "Alternate translation: "will be condemned in the judgment" or "will be condemned when God judges them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will not stand in the judgment

contextId.occurrenceNote: How people live is spoken of as if it were a "way" or "road" that they are walking on. Alternate translation: "how the righteous live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the way of the righteous

contextId.occurrenceNote: How people live and what they do is spoken of as if it were a "way" or "road" that they walk on. Possible meanings are 1) the way perishing represents the wicked perishing because of how they live. Alternate translation: "The wicked will die because of how they live" or 2) the way perishing is a metaphor for no longer being able to live the way they do. Alternate translation: "the wicked will no longer be able to live the way they live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the way of the wicked will perish

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of other nations speak of Yahweh and the Messiah's rule over them as if it were shackles and chains. Alternate translation: "We should free ourselves from their control; we should not let them rule over us any longer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Let us tear off the shackles ... throw off their chains

contextId.occurrenceNote: Defeating the nations is spoken of as breaking them, and his power is spoken of as an iron rod. Alternate translation: "You will defeat them completely by your power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will break them with an iron rod

contextId.occurrenceNote: Destroying nations is spoken of as if they could be smashed like a clay jar. Alternate translation: you will completely destroy them like a clay pot" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you will smash them to pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king's anger is spoken of as if it were a fire that could burn. Alternate translation: "when he suddenly becomes very angry" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: when his anger burns for just a moment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Asking the king for protection is spoken of as seeking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "ask the king to protect them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: seek refuge in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shield protects a soldier. David speaks as if God were a shield protecting him. Alternate translation: "you, Yahweh, protect me like a shield" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you, Yahweh, are a shield around me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "you are the one who lifts up my head." Giving someone courage is spoken of as lifting up his head. Alternate translation: "the one who encourages me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the one who lifts up my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Animals attack with their teeth. Breaking their teeth takes away their power to attack. David speaks as if Yahweh would come and physically fight against the wicked. Alternate translation: "you will make the wicked unable to harm me like someone breaking the teeth of a ferocious animal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will break the teeth of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being in danger is spoken of as being in a narrow space. Alternate translation: "rescue me when I am in danger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: give me room when I am hemmed in

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "trust" is spoken of as if it were an object that could be put somewhere. The abstract noun "trust" can be stated as a verb. Alternate translation: "trust in Yahweh" or "trust Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: put your trust in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards them as if Yahweh's face shone a light on them. Alternate translation: "act favorably towards us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: lift up the light of your face on us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "gladness" is spoken of as if it is an object that can be given. The abstract noun "gladness" can be stated as "glad." Alternate translation: "You have made me more glad than others are" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: You have given my heart more gladness than others have

contextId.occurrenceNote: Peace is spoken of as if it were a place. This can be restated to remove the abstract noun "peace." Alternate translation: "I will be peaceful when I lie down and sleep" or "I will not be afraid of danger when I lie down and sleep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: It is in peace that I will lie down and sleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of righteousness as if it were a path and of teaching as leading. The phrase "your righteousness" means that God is righteous Alternate translation: "teach me to do what is righteous as you do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: lead me in your righteousness

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of righteousness as if it were a path. A straight path is easy to see or walk on. Alternate translation: "show me clearly how to live in the right way" or "make it easy for me to do what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make your path straight before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Their throat is spoken of as if it were an open tomb, ready for dead bodies to put into it. Possible meanings are 1) "they say that they will kill people" or 2) "What they say kills people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their throat is an open tomb

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is something that causes a person to experience disasters or to lose power. Experiencing disaster or becoming less important is spoken of as falling. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: downfall

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he were a refuge, a place where people can be protected. Alternate translation: "May all those who go to you for protection rejoice" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: may all those who take refuge in you rejoice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to you for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of God being kind to him as God returning to him. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, come back to me" or "Have mercy on me, Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Return, Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being willing to do what David has prayed for is spoken of as accepting his prayer. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will respond to my prayer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has accepted my prayer

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to you for protection!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Waking up represents starting to do something or take action. Alternate translation: "Take action" or "Do something" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: wake up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ruling people is spoken of as being over them. Yahweh's rightful place refers either to heaven or to ruling in general. Alternate translation: "Rule over them from heaven" or "Rule over them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take once more your rightful place over them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shield" represents God's protection. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My shield comes from God

contextId.occurrenceNote: In verses 12 and 13, David speaks of God deciding to punish the wicked as if God were a warrior preparing to fight against them with weapons. Alternate translation: "God will take action against him like a warrior who sharpens his sword and prepares his bow for battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God will sharpen his sword and will prepare his bow for battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of the things that a wicked person does as if the person were pregnant and wickedness was the baby. Alternate translation: "the wicked person. He makes plans to destroy people and produces harmful lies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: one who is pregnant with wickedness ... conceives destructive plans ... gives birth to harmful lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Destruction and violence are spoken of as if they hit a person's head or fall down on it. Alternate translation: "His own destructive plans destroy him, for his violence attacks him" or "When he plans to destroy others, others destroy him; when he attacks others, others attack him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: His own destructive plans return to his own head, for his violence comes down on his own head

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) praise is spoken of as a solid object that God takes out of babies' mouths and sets up as a defensive wall or 2) God has created the world so that true praise comes to him from babies. Alternate translation: "You have given babies and infants the ability to praise you" or "It is babies and infants who truly praise you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Out of the mouth of babies and infants you have established praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Glory and honor are spoken of as if they were crowns. The words "glory" and "honor" are similar in meaning. Alternate translation: "have given them glory and honor" or "have caused them to be like kings" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: have crowned them with glory and honor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having authority to rule others or control things is spoken of as having them under one's feet. This means God gave people authority over all that he created. Alternate translation: "you have given him authority over all things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have put all things under his feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing people to be forgotten is spoken of as blotting out their name. Alternate translation: "you have caused them to be forgotten as if their name was blotted out" or "no one will ever remember them again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have blotted out their name forever and ever

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "remembrance" is spoken of as if it were a living being that could die. Alternate translation: "All remembrance of them has stopped" or "There is no longer any remembrance of them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: All remembrance of them has perished

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he were a place that people could go to for safety. Alternate translation: "Yahweh will also protect the oppressed" or "Yahweh will also provide safety for those who are oppressed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh also will be a stronghold for the oppressed

contextId.occurrenceNote: Death is spoken of as if it were a city that had gates through which people enter it. If someone is near the gates of death, it means that he will die soon. Keeping someone from dying is spoken of as taking him away from the gates of that city. Alternate translation: "you who can rescue me from death" or "you who can keep me from dying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you who can snatch me from the gates of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: People dig pits so they can catch animals that fall into them. Here digging a pit represents making plans to destroy people. Alternate translation: "The nations are like people who dig a pit for others and then fall into it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The nations have sunk down into the pit that they made

contextId.occurrenceNote: People hide nets so they can catch animals that get caught in them. Here hiding a net represents making plans to destroy people. Alternate translation: "they are like people who hide a net and get trapped in it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their feet are caught in the net that they hid

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hopes are spoken of as if they were objects that could be broken or destroyed. Hopes being destroyed represents the things that people hope for never happening. Alternate translation: "and the oppressed will not hope forever without results" or "and someday what the oppressed hope for will happen" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: nor will the hope of the oppressed be forever dashed

contextId.occurrenceNote: A raised face represents pride or arrogance. Alternate translation: "has an arrogant attitude" or "is proud" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has a raised face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Seeking God represents either 1) asking God for help or 2) thinking about God and obeying him. Alternate translation: "he does not ask God for help" or "he does not think about God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he does not seek God

contextId.occurrenceNote: Something that is hard to understand is spoken of as if it were too high to reach. Alternate translation: "he cannot understand your righteous decrees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your righteous decrees are too high for him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Experiencing adversity is spoken of as meeting it. Alternate translation: "I will not have any troubles" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not meet adversity

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the wicked person catching people as if he were a hunter using a net to catch animals. Alternate translation: "He catches the oppressed like a hunter that catches an animal in a net and drags it away" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He catches the oppressed when he pulls in his net

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer continues to speak of the wicked person catching people as if he were a hunter, his plans were nets, and the people were animals that fall into his net. Alternate translation: "his victims are caught by his plans like animals that fall into a hunter's strong nets" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they fall into his strong nets

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to pay attention to what people do is spoken of as forgetting. Alternate translation: "God does not pay attention" or "God does not care about what I do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God has forgotten

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to pay attention to what someone does is spoken of as covering one's face. Alternate translation: "God refuses to see what is happening" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he covers his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: Paying attention to what someone does is spoken of as looking at it. Alternate translation: "he will not bother to pay attention" or "he will not care" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will not bother to look

contextId.occurrenceNote: Starting to do something is spoken of as getting up. Alternate translation: "Do something" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Arise

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to Yahweh for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's punishment is described as if it were burning coals and brimstone from a volcano. Alternate translation: "He punishes the wicked; there will be no relief for them!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He rains burning coals and brimstone upon the wicked; a scorching wind will be their portion from his cup!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "flattering lips" is a metonym for people who flatter others. Possible meanings are 1) "cut off" is a metaphor for killing. Alternate translation: "kill all who flatter others" or 2) "cut off" is a metaphor for stopping something. Alternate translation: "stop all those who flatter others" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: cut off all flattering lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes those who desire to know God as if they were actually following him on a path. Alternate translation: "who desire to know him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who seek after him

contextId.occurrenceNote: This describes people who have rejected God as if they had stopped walking on the right path and had gone in another direction. Alternate translation: "They have all turned away from Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They have all turned away

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to those who do evil things and destroy God's people as if they were eating food. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who eat up my people

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the protection that Yahweh provides as if he were a shelter that one might seek in a storm. Alternate translation: "Yahweh is like a shelter of protection to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is his refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "to be shaken" represents not living safely any longer. This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: "will live in safety" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will never be shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to you for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a portion of land that has been given to him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my chosen portion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a cup that contains many blessings. Alternate translation: "the one who blesses me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my cup

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of Yahweh's blessings as if they were an inheritance that he has received. Alternate translation: "I am delighted with all the things that he has given me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: surely a pleasing inheritance is mine

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "give ear" is a metaphor for listening, and "lips without deceit" is synecdoche for a person who does not lie. Alternate translation: "Listen to my prayer for I speak without deceit" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Give ear to my prayer from lips without deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Vindication coming from God represents God judging someone and declaring him innocent. God's "presence" is a metonym for God himself. Alternate translation: "Let my vindication come from you" or "Declare that I am innocent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: Let my vindication come from your presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his obedience to God as if he were walking on a path. Alternate translation: "I am determined to follow your ways" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: my feet have not slipped

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to you for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of God's protection as if he were a bird protecting its young under its wings. Alternate translation: "Keep me safe as a mother bird protects her babies by gathering them under her wing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: hide me under the shadow of your wings

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for Yahweh's power and for violent death in war. Alternate translation: "by having them die in war" or "by killing them in battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: by your sword

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ancient text is hard to understand. Possible meanings are 1) "treasured" is a metaphor for loved, and "your treasured ones" refers to the people whom God loves. Alternate translation: "you will fill the bellies of the people you love with riches" or 2) "your treasured ones" refers to treasures that God gives to people, the "men of this world" Alternate translation: "you will fill their bellies with rich treasures" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will fill the bellies of your treasured ones with riches

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "fill the bellies ... with riches" is a metaphor for giving them many valuable things. Possible meanings are 1) "You will give many riches to the people you love" or 2) "you will give the men of this world many riches" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will fill the bellies ... with riches

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock. The word "rock" is a picture of a safe place. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to him for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a "shield," "the horn" of his salvation, and his "stronghold." Yahweh is the one who protects him from harm. Here a similar idea is repeated three ways for emphasis. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my shield, the horn of my salvation, and my stronghold

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of death as if it were a person who could capture him and bind him with ropes. Alternate translation: "I was about to be killed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: The cords of death surrounded me

contextId.occurrenceNote: David is as helpless as if he were being carried away by a rushing flood of waters. Alternate translation: "I felt completely helpless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: rushing waters of worthlessness

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's being angry is spoken of as if the there was a terrible earthquake. Alternate translation: "God was so angry that it was as if the earth ... shaken" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Then the earth ... shaken because God was angry

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were breathing fire. This is a picture of how angry God was. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Smoke went up from out of his nostrils ... Coals were ignited by it

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here darkness is spoken of as if it were a tent. Alternate translation: "He made darkness a covering" or "He made darkness a hiding place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He made darkness a tent

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here lighting strikes are being spoken of as if they were arrows (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He shot his arrows and scattered his enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the Psalmist speaks of the dangers of his enemies as if they were huge waves or forceful waters, from which Yahweh has rescued him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: surging water

contextId.occurrenceNote: The laws of Yahweh are spoken of as if they were the paths on which one should walk. Alternate translation: "I have obeyed Yahweh's laws" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have kept the ways of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here being wicked is spoken of as if one left the right path and took the wrong path. Alternate translation: "have not done wickedly by turning away from my God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: have not wickedly turned away from my God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's presence as if he were a light. These clauses have similar meanings. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: For you give light to my lamp; Yahweh my God lights up my darkness

contextId.occurrenceNote: A shield protects a soldier. David speaks as if God were a shield protecting him. See how you translated this in [Psalms 3:3](../003/003.md). Alternate translation: "You, Yahweh, protect like a shield everyone who takes refuge in you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He is a shield to everyone who takes refuge in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock that he could climb to get away from his enemies. See how you translated this in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of living a life that is pleasing to God as if he were being placed on the right path. Alternate translation: "causes the blameless person to live a righteous life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: places the blameless person on his path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer speaks of God's protection as if it were a shield. The abstract noun "salvation" can be stated with the verb "save." Alternate translation: "your protection and saved me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: the shield of your salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the safety that God has provided as if it were a wide place for him to stand. Here "my feet" represent the person. Alternate translation: "a safe place for me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: a wide place for my feet beneath me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer speaks of Yahweh's protection as if he were a rock that prevented his enemies from reaching him. See how you translated this in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's protection of the writer is spoken of as if he lifted the writer up so high that his enemies could not reach him to harm him. Alternate translation: "you put me in a safe place high above" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you lifted me above

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer speaks of the place that Yahweh created for the sun as if it were a tent. Alternate translation: "He created a place for the sun" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He has pitched a tent for the sun

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's decrees are spoken of as if they could be bought and tasted. Alternate translation: "If you could buy them, they would be of greater value than gold ... if you could taste them, they would be sweeter than honey" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They are of greater value than gold ... they are sweeter than honey

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in your judgment" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in your sight

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of God as if he were a rock that one could climb and be protected from his enemies. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, you are like my rock" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh, my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: God helping from his holy place is spoken of as if God were sending help. Alternate translation: "may Yahweh help you from his holy place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: send help from the holy place

contextId.occurrenceNote: "you have placed on him splendor and majesty." Causing the king to be wealthy and powerful is spoken of as if splendor and majesty are objects that are placed on him. Alternate translation: "you have made him wealthy and powerful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have bestowed on him splendor and majesty

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh or the king destroying their enemies is spoken of as if their enemies are wood and Yahweh or the king will throw them into a furnace. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will burn them up as in a fiery furnace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for "you" and "your" are 1) they refer to the king or 2) they refer to God and speak about him as if he were a warrior with a bow and arrows. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: For you will turn them back; you will draw your bow before them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer feeling like God is not listening to him is spoken of as if God were far from his words of anguish. Alternate translation: "why do you not listen when I speak to you about the anguish I feel" or "I have told you about my suffering but you do not come to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: far from the words of my anguish

contextId.occurrenceNote: "the praises of Israel are the throne on which you sit as king." The praises of Israel are described as if they are a throne upon which God can sit and rule, or as a house in which God can live. Alternate translation: "you are king and the people of Israel praise you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you sit as king with the praises of Israel

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of himself as if he were a worm. This emphasizes that he feels worthless or that the people treat him as if he were worthless. Alternate translation: "But it is like I am a worm and not a man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am a worm and not a man

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about "trouble" as if it were an object that is near him. Alternate translation: "for my enemies are near me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for trouble is near

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were bulls. This emphasizes how dangerous and powerful his enemies are. Alternate translation: "I have many enemies and they are like bulls that surround me; they are like strong bulls from Bashan that surround me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Many bulls surround me; strong bulls of Bashan surround me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were lions with the mouths open ready to eat him. His enemies may be speaking lies to discredit him. Or they may be threatening him and attacking him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They open their mouths wide against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "all my bones are out of place." It is possible the writer is in some kind of physical pain. Or he may be speaking of his emotional pain as if it were physical pain. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: all my bones are dislocated

contextId.occurrenceNote: "my tongue sticks to the top of my mouth." The writer may be describing his extreme thirst. Or he may be continuing to speak about being weak as if he were completely dry. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my tongue sticks to the roof of my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for "dust of death" are 1) it refers to a person turning to dust after they die. Alternate translation: "You are about to let me die and become dust" or 2) it is a way of speaking about the grave, which would mean God is causing the writer to die. Alternate translation: "You have laid me in my grave" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have laid me in the dust of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were dogs. His enemies are coming close to him like wild dogs do to a dying animal. Alternate translation: "my enemies are like dogs that have surrounded me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: dogs have surrounded me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This continues the dog metaphor. The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were dogs that are biting and piercing his hands and feet with their teeth. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they have pierced my hands and my feet

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the writer is so thin that he can see his bones. Alternate translation: "I can see all of my bones" or "I can feel each of my bones" or 2) this continues the dog metaphor and the writer can see his bones after the dogs have ripped his flesh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I can count all my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were dogs to emphasize how dangerous his enemies are. Also, the claws stand for the animals as a whole in a synecdoche. The writer emphasizes this part of the animal because it is what the animals would use to kill someone. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: claws of wild dogs

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were lions and wild oxen to emphasize how dangerous his enemies are. Also, the mouth and horns stand for the animals as a whole in a synecdoche. The writer emphasizes these parts of the animals because they are what the animals would use to kill someone. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: lion's mouth ... horns of the wild oxen

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hiding one's face from someone represents ignoring him. Alternate translation: "has not turned his attention away from him" or "has not ignored him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has not hidden his face from him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Those who want to know Yahweh and please him are spoken of as if they are literally seeking to find Yahweh. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who seek Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Starting to obey Yahweh is spoken of as if the people physically turn toward Yahweh. Alternate translation: "will remember Yahweh and obey him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will remember and turn to Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. This emphasizes how God cares for people as a shepherd cares for his sheep. Alternate translation: "Yahweh is like a shepherd to me" or "Yahweh cares for me as a shepherd cares for his sheep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is my shepherd

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about himself as if he were a sheep, and he speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. Alternate translation: He gives me rest like a shepherd who leads his sheep to lie down in green pastures" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He makes me to lie down in green pastures

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about himself as if he were a sheep, and he speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd. Alternate translation: "he provides what I need like a shepherd who leads his sheep beside tranquil water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he leads me beside tranquil water

contextId.occurrenceNote: Showing a person how to live in a way that pleases God is spoken of as if it were a shepherd showing a sheep the right path to take. Alternate translation: "He shows me how to live right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he guides me along right paths

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes a person experiencing terrible trouble as if he were a sheep walking through a dark and dangerous valley. There a sheep could get lost or attacked by a wild animal. Alternate translation: "Though my life is like walking through a dark and dangerous valley" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Even though I walk through a valley of darkest shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh being good and faithful to a person is spoken of as if goodness and covenant faithfulness are things that pursue after a person. The abstract nouns "goodness" and "faithfulness" can be translated as adjectives. Alternate translation: "Surely you will be good and faithful to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely goodness and covenant faithfulness will pursue me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to the temple to worship Yahweh is spoken of as if the person is literally seeking to find him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who seek him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about Yahweh as if he were a mighty warrior who fights in battles. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh, strong and mighty; Yahweh, mighty in battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "lift up my life" is a metaphor. Possible meanings are 1) the writer is giving himself to Yahweh, which means he is completely depending on Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I give myself to you" or 2) he is offering prayer and adoration to Yahweh. Alternate translation: "I worship and adore you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I lift up my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: How God wants a person to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path on which a person travels. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the way

contextId.occurrenceNote: How God wants a person to behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path on which a person travels. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "paths" is a metaphor for ways. Alternate translation: "Yahweh always loves us because of his covenant and he is always trustworthy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: All the paths of Yahweh are steadfast love and faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh teaching people how they should behave is spoken of as if Yahweh were teaching the people what way or path they should travel. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The Lord will instruct him in the way that he should choose

contextId.occurrenceNote: A net is a trap. A person who is in danger is spoken of as if their feet are tangled in a net. Alternate translation: He will rescue me from danger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for he will free my feet from the net

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh paying attention to a person and considering him is spoken of as if Yahweh were physically turning towards the person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn toward me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "bring me out of my distress." This speaks of distress as if it were a place that a person can be brought out of. Alternate translation: "rescue me from my distress" or "relieve me of my distress" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: draw me out from my distress

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to you for protection!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you!

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "walked" is a metaphor for behavior. Alternate translation: "I have behaved" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have walked

contextId.occurrenceNote: Doubting is spoken of as if it were losing balance and waving back and forth. Alternate translation: "without doubting" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: without wavering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "eyes" represent a person's thoughts and having something before one's eyes represents being aware of that thing. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be translated as an adjective. Alternate translation: "For I am always aware of your covenant faithfulness" or "For I am always aware that you are faithful to your covenant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: For your covenant faithfulness is before my eyes

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "walk" is a metaphor for behavior. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be translated with an adjective. Alternate translation: "I conduct my life according to your faithfulness" or "I behave the way I do because you are faithful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: I walk about in your faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Sweep away" here is a metaphor for destruction. Alternate translation: "Do not destroy me along with sinners" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not sweep me away with sinners

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Walk" here is a metaphor for behavior. Alternate translation: "I will behave with integrity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk in integrity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that "level ground" represents 1) a safe place or 2) right behavior (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: level ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about Yahweh as if he were a place where people can go for safety. Alternate translation: "Yahweh is the one who keeps me safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is my life's refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Destroying someone completely is spoken of as if it were devouring a person's flesh. He did not mean that they wanted to eat his body. Alternate translation: "to destroy me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to devour my flesh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents the writer's enemies failing to fulfill their plans to harm the writer. Alternate translation: "did not succeed" or "failed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: stumbled and fell

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's enemies are spoken of as if they themselves were a war. Alternate translation: "though my enemies come to fight against me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: though war rises up against me

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person really wanting something and continually asking God for it is spoken of as if he were seeking to find something. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will seek that

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wonderful character of God is spoken of as if it were physical beauty. Alternate translation: "to see how wonderful Yahweh is" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to see the beauty of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: God keeping the writer safe from his enemies is spoken of as if God were placing him on a high rock where his enemies cannot reach him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will lift me high on a rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person going to the temple to pray to Yahweh is spoken of as if the person were seeking to find Yahweh. Here "face" represents all of God. Alternate translation: "Go and pray to Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: Seek his face

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person going to the temple to pray to Yahweh is spoken of as if the person were seeking to find Yahweh. Here "face" represents all of God. Alternate translation: "I will come to your temple to pray to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I seek your face, Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: How a person should behave is spoken of as if it were a way or path that person should travel. Alternate translation: "Teach me how you want me to live" or "Teach me to do what you want me to do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Teach me your way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh keeping the writer safe from his enemies is spoken of as if Yahweh leads the writer on a level path where he will not stumble and fall. Alternate translation: "Keep me safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Lead me on a level path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here violence is spoken for as if it was something a person could breathe out. Alternate translation: "they say that they will do violent things to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they breathe out violence

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor for strength. Alternate translation: "my strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who die are spoken of as if they are going down into the grave. Alternate translation: "I will die like those who are in the grave" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will join those who go down to the grave

contextId.occurrenceNote: God punishing people is spoken of as if he physically drags them away. In this metaphor Yahweh may be dragging them to prison, exile, or death. Alternate translation: "Do not remove me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not drag me away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The punishment of the wicked people is spoken of as if they were a building or a city that God would destroy. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will tear them down and never rebuild them

contextId.occurrenceNote: This represents Yahweh's protecting the writer. Alternate translation: "he protects me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh keeping the king safe is spoken of as if Yahweh were a place that the king could go for safety. Alternate translation: "he keeps safe the one he appointed to be king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he is the saving refuge of his anointed one

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about the people of God as if they were something God inherited. Alternate translation: "your possession" or "those who belong to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about Yahweh as if he were a shepherd and the people are his sheep. A shepherd would carry a sheep if it needed help or protection. Alternate translation: "Be like their shepherd and protect them forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Be their shepherd and carry them forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about God speaking as if it were the sound of thunder. Just like the sound of thunder, Yahweh's voice can be heard over large distances. Alternate translation: "The voice of the glorious God is loud like thunder" or "When the glorious God speaks it rumbles like thunder" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the God of glory thunders

contextId.occurrenceNote: Removing the leaves of the trees is spoken of as if it was removing their clothing. Alternate translation: "strips off the leaves from the trees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: strips the forests bare

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of God rescuing him and keeping him from dying as if God had drawn him up from a deep well. Alternate translation: "you rescued me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have raised me up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about "weeping" and "joy" as if they were something that travels and arrives at a certain time. Alternate translation: "We may cry during the night, but the next morning we will be joyful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Weeping comes for a night, but joy comes in the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shaken" is a metaphor for defeat. Alternate translation: "No one will defeat me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will never be shaken

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's security is spoken of as if he were a strong mountain. Alternate translation: "you made me as secure as a high mountain" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you established me as a strong mountain

contextId.occurrenceNote: The phrase "sought favor" means to ask for help. Alternate translation: "I pleaded for you to help me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: sought favor from my Lord

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of gladness as if it were a garment that he could put on. Alternate translation: "caused me to be glad" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: clothed me with gladness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "I go to you, Yahweh, for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In you, Yahweh, I take refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoke of as if he were a huge rock that would protect the writer from attack. Alternate translation: "like a huge rock on which I can be safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my rock of refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a strong fortress in which the writer would be protected from his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a stronghold to save me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoke of as if he were a huge rock that would protect the writer from attack. Alternate translation: "like a huge rock on which I can be safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a strong fortress in which the writer would be protected from his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my fortress

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer is spoken of as if he were a bird caught in a hidden net, and waiting for Yahweh to free him from the trap. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Pluck me out of the net that they have hidden for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he is a place where the writer can hide from people who are attacking him. Alternate translation: "you always protect me" or "you give me constant protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you are my refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Hebrews thought of wide open spaces as a metaphor for safety and freedom. Alternate translation: "a place where I am free" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a wide open place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards him as if Yahweh's face shone a light on him. Alternate translation: "Act favorably towards your servant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Make your face shine on your servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's goodness is spoken of as if it was something that could be stored up like a harvest. Alternate translation: "that you are keeping ready to use" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that you have stored up

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. See how you translated this in [Psalms 31:1](../031/001.md). Alternate translation: "those who go to you for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in you

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's presence is spoken of as if it is a strong building where the writer would be safe. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In the shelter

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sin that is forgiven is spoken of as if it were covered so that it can not be seen. Alternate translation: "whose sin is ignored" or "whose sin is deliberately forgotten" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: whose sin is covered

contextId.occurrenceNote: Difficulties are spoken of as if they were a flood of water. Alternate translation: "Then when difficulties come like a flood of water, those people will be safe" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: When the surging waters overflow, the waters will not reach them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he was a safe place from the attacks of the writer's enemies. Alternate translation: "You are like a place where I can hide myself from my enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You are my hiding place

contextId.glQuote: You will surround me with the songs of victory

contextId.occurrenceNote: Living in the correct way is spoken of as if it were a path that the writer should walk. Alternate translation: "how you should live your life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the way which you should go

contextId.glQuote: Yahweh's covenant faithfulness will surround the one who trusts in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "upright" is used as a metaphor for something that is true. Alternate translation: "Yahweh always does what he says that he will do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh's word is upright

contextId.occurrenceNote: People everywhere in the world being able to see evidence of Yahweh's covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if his covenant faithfulness filled the earth. The abstract noun "covenant faithfulness" can be translated as an adjective. Alternate translation: "People everywhere on earth can see that Yahweh is faithful to his covenant" or "Throughout the earth, there is evidence that Yahweh is faithful to his covenant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth is full of Yahweh's covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes the creation of the oceans as if God put them in a storehouse. Alternate translation: "he puts the oceans in their place, just like a man puts grain in a storehouse" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he puts the oceans in storehouses

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people Yahweh has chosen to worship him are described here as if they were an inheritance that he has received. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: as his own inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place where Yahweh lives is spoken of as if it is above the earth where people live. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he looks down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here Yahweh is spoken of as if he is a shield that protects soldiers in battle. Alternate translation: "he is our helper and protects us like a shield" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he is our help and our shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh acting faithfully towards the people is spoken of as if Yahweh's covenant faithfulness were with them. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be translated with an adverb. Alternate translation: "May you always act faithfully towards us because of your covenant, Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Let your covenant faithfulness, Yahweh, be with us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "sought Yahweh" means David was asking Yahweh for help. Alternate translation: "I prayed to Yahweh" or "I asked Yahweh for help" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I sought Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "look to" represents seeking help from him. Alternate translation: "Those who look at him for help" or "those who expect help only from him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who look to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The angel of Yahweh is spoken of as if he were an army that camps around someone in order to protect them. Alternate translation: "guards" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: camps around

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's goodness is spoken of as something that can be tasted and seen. Alternate translation: "Try and experience that Yahweh is good" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Taste and see that Yahweh is good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is spoken of as if he were a place where people can hide for protection from their enemies. Alternate translation: "trust him to protect them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: takes refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "Turn away" is a metaphor for avoiding evil. Alternate translation: "Refuse to do evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn away from evil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seek" means to be concerned about peace. Alternate translation: "Try hard to live in peace with other people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Seek peace

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh will cause people to so completely forget them when they die that it is as if he used a knife to cut off any memory of them. Alternate translation: "so that when they are dead, people will forget them completely" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to cut off the memory of them from the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a nominal adjective that refers to people who are brokenhearted. Deep sadness is spoken of as if the person's heart is broken. contextId.glQuote: the brokenhearted

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who are deeply discouraged are spoken of as if their spirits are crushed. Alternate translation: "people who are deeply discouraged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who are crushed in spirit

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "go to him for protection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: take refuge in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes God as a warrior who is preparing himself for battle. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Grab your small shield and large shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes God as a warrior who is preparing himself for battle. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Use your spear and battle ax

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) these enemies are literally chasing the writer or 2) this is a metaphor for people who are enemies of the writer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those who chase me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "seek my life" means they desire to kill the writer. The writer is represented by his "life." Alternate translation: "who are trying to kill me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: who seek my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: "be turned back" here is a metaphor for being unable to accomplish their goal. Alternate translation: "be unsuccessful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: be turned back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to a way that is hidden and dangerous. Alternate translation: "hidden and full of dangers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: dark and slippery

contextId.occurrenceNote: This refers to the angel of Yahweh being opposed to the writer's enemies. Alternate translation: "works against them" or "opposes them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: chases them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a net that they set to catch the writer. Alternate translation: "they want to catch me in a net like a small animal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they set their net for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a pit that they dug to catch the writer. Alternate translation: "they wanted to capture me in a pit like a big animal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they dug a pit for my life

contextId.occurrenceNote: The schemes of the wicked are spoken of as if they were a net that they place to catch the writer. Alternate translation: "the net that they placed in order to capture me like an animal and harm me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the net that they have set

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is the same metaphor as in verse 7. The net is intended to catch the writer. Alternate translation: "Let them fall into the pit that they dug for me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: Let them fall into it

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor which means they give back evil in exchange for the good they have received. Alternate translation: "In return for my doing good things for them, they do evil things to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They repay me evil for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the treated the writer as if he were a piece of cloth that they could tear to pieces. Alternate translation: "They attacked me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They tore at me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer speaks of his enemies as if they were vicious lions. Alternate translation: "from my enemies who attack me like wild animals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: from the lions

contextId.occurrenceNote: This does not mean that God is actually asleep. The writer wants God to intervene. Both words mean basically the same thing and emphasize the urgency of this request. contextId.glQuote: Arouse yourself and awake

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's enemies speak of his destruction as if they were wild animals who had eaten him. Alternate translation: "We have swallowed him up" or "We have destroyed him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: We have devoured him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sinful actions of the man are spoken of as if he was walking along a path that was evil. Alternate translation: "he begins to do evil things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he sets out on an evil way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The greatness of God's covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if it were an object that reached as high as the heavens. contextId.glQuote: Your covenant faithfulness ... reaches to the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The greatness of God's loyalty is spoken of as if it was very high. Alternate translation: "is as high as the clouds" or "is enormously great" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: reaches to the clouds

contextId.occurrenceNote: Eating much food as guests in a house is a metaphor for God providing all his people need. contextId.glQuote: in your light we will see light

contextId.glQuote: Extend your covenant faithfulness fully to those who know you

contextId.occurrenceNote: All three phrases describe the evildoers as defeated. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Faithfulness is spoken of as if it was an animal that would be strengthened by feeding in good pasture. Alternate translation: "nourish faithfulness" or "increase your faithfulness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: graze in faithfulness

contextId.glQuote: will be cut off

contextId.glQuote: Turn away from

contextId.glQuote: he will raise you up to possess the land

contextId.glQuote: is cut off

contextId.glQuote: they have taken refuge in him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The severity of Yahweh's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if Yahweh had shot arrows into the writer. Alternate translation: "Your punishment is as painful as if you had shot arrows into me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if Yahweh was smashing the writer with his hand. Here, "hand" refers to Yahweh's power. contextId.glQuote: your hand presses me down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's iniquities are spoken of as if they are a flood of water that covers him. Alternate translation: "my iniquities cover me like a flood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my iniquities overwhelm me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's iniquities are spoken of as if they are a heavy load that he cannot lift. Alternate translation: "they are like a load that is too heavy for me to lift" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they are a burden too heavy for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The pain of the writer's wounds have caused him to be bent over as if he were an old, feeble man. Alternate translation: "I am bent over in pain" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am stooped over

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's is so sick with fever that it is as if he is burning inside. Alternate translation: "My body is burning with fever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am filled with burning

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's illness is so severe that it is as if a huge weight is pressing down on him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: utterly crushed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The plots of the writer's enemies are spoken of as if they were traps that they had set to catch him like an animal. Alternate translation: "set traps to catch me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: lay snares for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for this metaphor are 1) "I am so sick that I am about to die" or 2) "I will soon be ruined." It may be best not to interpret the metaphor in the text. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am about to stumble

contextId.occurrenceNote: The actions of the writer's enemies are spoken of as a financial transaction where they gave him evil things in exchange for good things. contextId.glQuote: They repay me evil for good

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way the writer's enemies accuse him is spoken of as if they were throwing accusations at him like rocks. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: hurl accusations at me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writers desire for what is good is spoken of as if he were running after good things. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pursued what is good

contextId.occurrenceNote: Because Yahweh has not yet answered the writer's request, he speaks of Yahweh as if Yahweh were standing far away from the writer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: do not stay far away from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he is running to the writer to help him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Come quickly to help me

contextId.occurrenceNote: To "muzzle" means to keep a mouth shut. Here David means that he will not speak while he is with an evil person. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: muzzle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his lifespan is if it could be measured by the width of his hand. Alternate translation: "only a very short time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: only the width of my hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: Life is short, and the psalmist speaks of it here as if it were only as long as the time it takes for a person to breathe one breath. Alternate translation: "The time that humans live is as short as a single breath of a person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely every man is a single breath

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if God was wounding him with a weapon. Alternate translation: "Please stop punishing me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Stop wounding me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's punishment of the writer is spoken of as if God was striking him with his fist. Here "hand" represents God's judgment. Alternate translation: "your judgment on me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the blow of your hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the frailty of people as if they were mist that disappears quickly. Alternate translation: "everyone is completely fragile" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: all people are nothing but vapor

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's lack of response to him as if Yahweh was deaf. Alternate translation: "Do not ignore me as if you could not hear me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not be deaf to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here troubles are spoken of as if they were objects that surround and trap the speaker. Alternate translation: "there are more troubles around me than I can count" or "more troubles come to me than I can count" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Troubles that cannot be numbered surround me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "pursue my life" means they desire to kill the writer. The writer is represented by his "life." Alternate translation: "who are trying to kill me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who pursue my life to take it away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of revenge on his enemies as if it were paying to them what he owes. Alternate translation: "so that I may take revenge on them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: so that I may pay them back

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of being in Yahweh's presence as being in a place where Yahweh can see him and he can see Yahweh's face. Alternate translation: "will keep me with you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will keep me before your face

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of his strong desire for God as if it were a strong thirst for water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I thirst for you, God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of his strong desire for God as if it were a strong thirst for water. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I thirst for God
