Alternate translation: "Lord, you destroy the people as with a flood and they die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You sweep them away as with a flood and they sleep

contextId.occurrenceNote: God destroying people in his anger is spoken of as if God's anger were a fire that completely burns up the people. This can be stated in active form. Alternate translation: "You destroy us in your anger" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: we are consumed in your anger

contextId.occurrenceNote: God considering people's sins is spoken of as if sins were an objects he could place in front of himself and look at them. Alternate translation: "You see every sinful thing we do, even the sinful things we do in secret" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You have set our iniquities before you, our hidden sins in the light of your presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: Asking Yahweh to no longer be angry is spoken of as if the writer wants God to turn physically away from his anger. Alternate translation: "Yahweh, please do not be angry any longer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn back, Yahweh! How long will it be?

contextId.occurrenceNote: Because "live" and "stay" mean almost the same thing, as do "shelter" and "shadow," which are both metaphors for protection, you may need to combine the two lines into one. Alternate translation: "The Most High, the Almighty, will care for all those who live where he can protect them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: He who lives ... will stay ... of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shelter" is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: "who lives where the Most High protects him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who lives in the shelter of the Most High

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "shadow" here is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: "will stay where the Almighty can protect him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: will stay in the shadow of the Almighty

contextId.occurrenceNote: A "refuge" is any place a person can go and have someone or something protect him. A "fortress" is something that people make so they can protect themselves and their property. Asaph uses them here as metaphors for protection. Alternate translation: "the one to whom I can go and he will protect me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my refuge and my fortress

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's protection is here referred to as "wings" which a bird uses to cover its' young from danger. "Cover you with his wings" and "under his wings" mean basically the same thing. Alternate translation: "He will keep you safe and protect you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: He will cover you with his wings, and under his wings you will find refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's trustworthiness is here referred to as a "shield" which can protect people who rely on him. The abstract noun "trustworthiness" can be stated as "trust." Alternate translation: "You can trust him to protect you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: His trustworthiness is a shield and protection

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh protecting him as if Yahweh were a safe place for him to find protection from his enemies. Alternate translation: "Yahweh protects me, like a person finds protection in a place of refuge" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh is my refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of a person experiencing bad or evil things as if evil were a person who overtakes another person. Alternate translation: "Nothing evil will happen to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: No evil will overtake you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of the way a person lives his life as if it were a path down which the person walked. Alternate translation: "in everything you do" or "at all times" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in all your ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Where "hit your foot on a stone" is a minor problem, lions and snake are examples of great dangers. The psalmist speaks of lions and snakes as if they were small enough to be crushed under a person's foot. Alternate translation: "You will be able kill lions and adders as if they were small animals you could crush under your feet" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You will crush lions and adders under your feet; you will trample on young lions and serpents

contextId.occurrenceNote: "and I will show him my salvation." The psalmist speaks of the work God does to save people as if it were a physical object. Alternate translation: "I will save him so that he knows I am the one who saved him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: and show him my salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that the oil that God has put on the psalmist is a metaphor for God 1) making him happy "you have made me very happy" or 2) making him strong, "you have made me strong" or 3) enabling him to defeat his enemies, "you have enabled me to defeat my enemies." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am anointed with fresh oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of people who truly worship God as if they were trees growing in Yahweh's house. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the house of Yahweh ... in the courts of our God

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were healthy trees. Alternate translation: "they are growing well" or "they are very strong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they flourish

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were trees that produce food. Alternate translation: "They please God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They bear fruit

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of righteous people as if they were trees. Alternate translation: "they remain strong and healthy" or "they always do what pleases God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they stay fresh and green

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Yahweh is the one who protects me." The psalmist speaks of Yahweh as if he were a rock that would protect him. See how this is translated in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He is my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's strength and majesty as if they were things Yahweh wears. Alternate translation: "he shows everyone that he is a powerful king" or "his majesty is there for all to see, like the robe a king wears; everything about Yahweh shows that he is strong and he is ready to do great work" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he is robed in majesty; Yahweh has clothed and girded himself with strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of where God lives as if it were high above the earth. Alternate translation: "in heaven" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: on high

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's house as if it were a woman wearing beautiful clothing or jewelry and of Yahweh's holiness as the beautiful clothing or jewelry. Alternate translation: "your house is beautiful because you are holy" or "your holiness makes your house beautiful the way beautiful clothes and jewelry make a woman more beautiful" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: holiness adorns your house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "shine" is a metaphor for God revealing himself. Alternate translation: "show yourself" or "reveal your glory" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: shine over us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist writes of the wicked speaking as if their words were a liquid being poured out. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They pour out their arrogant words

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of powerful people treating powerless people badly as if it were crushing them or breaking them in pieces. See how "break in pieces" is translated in [Psalms 72:4](../072/004.md). Alternate translation: "They completely destroy" or "They greatly harm" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: They crush

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the thoughts of men are compared to vapor or steam that disappears into the air. This metaphor shows how unimportant and useless they are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that they are vapor

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "tower" is a metaphor for protection. Alternate translation: "Yahweh has protected me from my enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh has been my high tower

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of having God protect him as if God were a place where the psalmist could go to be safe. See how "rock" and "refuge" are translated in [Psalms 62:7](../062/007.md). Alternate translation: "I have asked God to protect me, and he has kept me safe by his power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God has been the rock of my refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh as if Yahweh were a mountain the people could climb so they would be safe. See how "rock" and "of my salvation" are translated in [Psalms 18:46](../018/046.md). Alternate translation: "the rock where we can go and God will save us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the rock of our salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. Alternate translation: "go to where he is" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: enter his presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "hand" here refers to how Yahweh protects his people the way a shepherd protects his sheep. Alternate translation: "the people whom he protects like a shepherd protects his sheep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the sheep of his hand

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two phrases are both metaphors for the people seeing how much evil they could do before Yahweh would punish them. The phrases say basically the same thing and can be combined. Alternate translation: "tested me" or "wanted to see if they could do evil things without my punishing them ... tested whether I would continue to be patient with them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: tested me ... tried me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the people as if they were sheep, which will go wherever they want to and not stay near their shepherd. Alternate translation: "move away from me" or "go their own way" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: wander astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's commands are spoken of as if they were paths on which the people should walk. The people not obeying Yahweh's commands is spoken of as if they did not know these paths. Alternate translation: "they have not obeyed my commands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they have not known my ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if those who were strong enough to rule were the physically higher than others. Alternate translation: "rule over all the people who live on" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: are most high above all

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if those who were strong enough to rule were the physically higher than others. Alternate translation: "You are high, far" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You are exalted far

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "sown" is a metaphor for actions with future results. "Light" is a metaphor for good things. Alternate translation: "Yahweh plans for good things to happen to the righteous in the future" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Light is sown for the righteous

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if he is telling the readers to go into the throne room of a king. Alternate translation: "go to where he is with joyful singing" or "he can hear you, so sing joyfully" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: come before his presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's people are like his sheep. Alternate translation: "the people God provides for and protects" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the sheep of his pasture

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about "living" as if it were "walking." Alternate translation: "I will live in a way that is honest and right" or "I will live a life full of integrity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk in the way of integrity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about "living" as if it were walking." Also, David speaks of overseeing his house with integrity, as if integrity were a physical object residing in his house. Alternate translation: "I will oversee my house with integrity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk with integrity within my house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about "living" as if it were "walking." Alternate translation: "live in a way that is honest and right" or "live lives full of integrity" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: walk in the way of integrity

contextId.occurrenceNote: God has not literally lifted and thrown David's body to the ground; rather David says this to describe what he is feeling and experiencing. Alternate translation: "it is like you have lifted me up to throw me down" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have lifted me up to throw me down

contextId.occurrenceNote: David describes God causing him to become weak as if his strength were a physical item that could be taken away from him. Alternate translation: "has caused me to become weak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: taken away my strength

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "days" here refers to his life. Alternate translation: "my life" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my days

contextId.occurrenceNote: David is asking God to not let him die. Alternate translation: "do not take me away from the earth" or "do not let me die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: do not take me away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes the length of time that God is alive as his "years." This can be written in positive form. Alternate translation: "you will live forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublenegatives]])
contextId.glQuote: your years will have no end

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes the descendants being protected by Yahweh as being in his presence. Alternate translation: "be protected as they live in your presence" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: live in your presence

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that Yahweh keeps him alive. Alternate translation: "He saves me from dying" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He redeems your life from destruction

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here blessing someone and treating them with great honor is described as if it were placing a crown on that person's head. The abstract nouns "faithfulness" and "mercy" can be translated with adverbs. Alternate translation: "he blesses you by acting faithfully and mercifully towards you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: he crowns you with covenant faithfulness and acts of tender mercy

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the clouds are described as carrying Yahweh as if they were a chariot. Alternate translation: "you make the clouds carry you like a chariot" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you make the clouds your chariot

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the blowing of the wind is described as wings on which Yahweh walks. Alternate translation: "you walk upon the wind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you walk on the wings of the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes birds chirping as if they were singing. Alternate translation: "they chirp among the tree branches" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they sing among the branches

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means that God causes it to rain. The waters are described as residing in chambers in the sky. Alternate translation: "He waters the mountains by causing the rains to fall from the sky" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He waters the mountains from his water chambers in the sky

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes the amount of things that Yahweh had created as if they were a liquid overflowing out of a container. Alternate translation: "is filled with your work" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: overflows with your works

contextId.occurrenceNote: He is comparing his thoughts to something that tastes sweet. Alternate translation: "my thoughts be pleasing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my thoughts be sweet

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the increase of Israel as if they were a plant that produced a lot of fruit. "God increased the number of his people greatly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh made his people fruitful

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the psalmist describes Yahweh placing a cloud in the sky as if he were spreading out a garment. The cloud was a "covering" to protect them from the sun. Alternate translation: "He placed a cloud in the sky to protect them from the sun and heat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: He spread a cloud for a covering

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about Yahweh causing the people to be afflicted by a disease as if Yahweh sent a disease to them in the same way that someone sends a person or a messenger. Alternate translation: "but he caused them to suffer from a horrible disease" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but he sent a horrible disease

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about Moses persuading Yahweh not to destroy the Israelites as intervening with him in the breach. Alternate translation: "stood between Yahweh and the Israelites and begged Yahweh to not destroy them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: stood in the breach before him, to turn away his anger from destroying them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Hey David speaks of the people intermarrying with the women from other nations as "mingling" with them. Alternate translation: "but they mixed in marriage with the other nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but they mingled with the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes Yahweh saving them from their distress as if their distress were a physical place that he was bringing them out of. Alternate translation: "he saved" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he brought

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the act of "dying" is described as a place, "the gates of death" Alternate translation: "they almost died" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they came close to the gates of death

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes the winds causing the waves to become high as if the wind was an object fiercely stirring something. Alternate translation: "that caused the waves of the sea to become very high" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that stirs up the seas

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of Yahweh showing contempt for the leaders as if contempt were a liquid he poured out on them. Alternate translation: "shows contempt for" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pours contempt on

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist is asking God to show that he is exalted. Being exalted above the heavens represents being great. Alternate translation: "God, show that you are exalted above the heavens" or "God, show that you are great in the heavens" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Be exalted, God, above the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes God speaking something because he is holy as speaking "in his holiness," as if his holiness were something that he was physically inside of. Alternate translation: "God, because he is holy, has said" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: God has spoken in his holiness

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of the tribe of Ephraim as if it were his army. The helmet symbolizes equipment for war. Alternate translation: "Ephraim is like a helmet I have chosen" or "The tribe of Ephraim is my army" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Ephraim also is my helmet

contextId.occurrenceNote: God chose men from the tribe of Judah to be the kings of his people, and he speaks of that tribe as if it were his scepter. Alternate translation: "The tribe of Judah is like my scepter" or "Judah is the tribe through whom I rule my people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Judah is my scepter

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of Moab being unimportant as if Moab were a washbasin or a lowly servant. Alternate translation: "Moab is like a bowl that I use for washing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Moab is my washbasin

contextId.occurrenceNote: God was probably speaking of taking ownership of Edom as if he were symbolically throwing his shoe onto that land to show that he owns it. However some versions have other interpretations. Alternate translation: "I take ownership of the land of Edom" or "I throw my shoe onto the land of Edom to show that it is mine" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: over Edom I will throw my shoe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of God helping their army as if God were to go and fight with them. Alternate translation: "you do not help our army when we go into battle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: You do not go into battle with our army

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of God helping their army defeat their enemies as if God were to trample down the enemies. Alternate translation: "he will enable us to trample down our enemies" or "he will make us able to defeat our enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he will trample down our enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the idea of there being no one to carry on the family name is spoke of as "their name being blotted out." Alternate translation: "may there be no one to carry on his name" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: may their name be blotted out in the next generation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks about Yahweh thinking about their guilt as if their guilt is something physically present before him. Alternate translation: "May Yahweh continually think about their sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: May their guilt always be before Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of the wicked person's behavior as if it were his clothing. Alternate translation: "He cursed other people as often as he wore clothing" or "He cursed people all the time" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He clothed himself with cursing as his garment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are: 1) He spoke curses so often that they became a part of his identity. "the curses that he speaks are part of who he is" or 2) the curse that he spoke happened to him. "his whole being was cursed by the curse he spoke" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his curse came into his inner being like water, like oil into his bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of being in great despair as his heart being wounded. Alternate translation: "I am full of grief and despair" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my heart is wounded within me

contextId.occurrenceNote: David feels like he is going to die soon and describes this feeling by comparing himself to a fading shadow and to how the wind blows away locust. Alternate translation: "I feel like I am about to die, like an evening shadow that will soon disappear, like a locust is easily blown away by the wind" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am fading away like the shadow ... like a locust

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David speaks of them being ashamed as if were clothing they wore. Alternate translation: "be very ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: be clothed with shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David describes Yahweh placing his master's enemies under his power and control as putting them under his feet like a footstool. Alternate translation: "put your enemies under your power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: make your enemies your footstool

contextId.occurrenceNote: David is telling the king that he will have youthful strength each morning by comparing it to how the dew appears early each morning. Alternate translation: "each morning you will be filled with youthful strength to sustain you just like each morning the dew appears to water and sustain the earth" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: from the womb of the dawn your youth will be to you like the dew

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the land that belonged to the nations in Canaan as if it were their inheritance. Alternate translation: "the land that belonged to other nations" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the inheritance of the nations

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of God blessing the godly person in difficult times as if it were a light shining in darkness. Alternate translation: "The blessings that a godly person receives from God are like a light that shines in the darkness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Light shines in the darkness for the godly person

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the wicked person's eventual death as if that person were something, such as ice, that can melt. Alternate translation: "eventually die" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: melt away

contextId.occurrenceNote: The glory of God is spoken of as if it was very high. Alternate translation: "his glory is higher than the skies" or "his glory is enormously great" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his glory reaches above the skies

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield because he protects his people as a shield would protect them from harm. Alternate translation: "the one who helps you and protects you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your help and shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the grave or the place of the dead as a place of silence where no one can speak. This is a euphemism for death. Alternate translation: "nor do any who go to the place of the dead" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-euphemism]])
contextId.glQuote: nor do any who go down into silence

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of being humbled as in being in a lower position. Alternate translation: "I was helpless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I was brought low

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of having peace and confidence as if it were a place where his soul can rest. The word "soul" represents the person. Alternate translation: "I can rest in peace again" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: My soul can return to its resting place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of being in danger of dying as if he had been chained in prison. Alternate translation: "you have saved me from death" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you have taken away my bonds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh saving him from distress as if Yahweh had taken him from a place of confinement to a wide open space where he could move about freely. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set me free

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he were a shelter, a place where people can be protected. Alternate translation: "to seek protection from Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to take shelter in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This verse is parallel to the one preceding it. God is spoken of as if he were a refuge, a place where people can be protected. Alternate translation: "to seek protection from Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to take refuge in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of defeating the enemy armies as if he were cutting them off like a person would cut a branch off of a plant. Alternate translation: "I defeated them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I cut them off

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the enemy armies trying to defeat him as if they were trying to push him down onto the ground. Alternate translation: "in order to defeat me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: to knock me down

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh blessing his people as if Yahweh were shining a light on them. Alternate translation: "he has blessed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has given us light

contextId.occurrenceNote: How a person behaves is spoken of as "ways" or "paths." Alternate translation: "those whose behavior is blameless" or "those whom no one can blame for doing wrong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: those whose ways are blameless

contextId.occurrenceNote: The way a person lives or behaves is spoken of as walking. Alternate translation: "who live according to the law of Yahweh" or "who obey the law of Yahweh." This phrase clarifies the meaning of "whose ways are blameless" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who walk in the law of Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of being established in God's commandments as if no one could physically make him move. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I would be firmly established

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares living according to God's law as a path kept clear of obstructions. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: keep his path pure

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here to disobey God's commandments is described as straying off a path. Alternate translation: "Do not let me disobey your commandments" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not let me stray from your commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I have put your words in my heart." This is a metaphor that means "I have memorized your word." The heart is pictured as a container that can hold what people think. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have stored up your word in my heart

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of gaining understanding, knowledge and wisdom as being able to see. Alternate translation: Help me to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Open my eyes so that I may see

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author speaks of insight into the law as objects to marvel at. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: marvelous things in your law

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) the writers speaks of his short life on earth as if he were a foreigner who would not stay long in the land. Alternate translation: "I am like a foreigner living a short time in the land" or 2) the writer's ignorance of God's law as if he were a foreigner who did not know the laws of the land. Alternate translation: "I am ignorant like a foreigner in the land" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I am a foreigner in the land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his desires being very strong as if they were in pain. Alternate translation: "My inner being strongly desires to know" or "My soul aches because I want so much to know" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: My desires are crushed by the longing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of disobeying God's commandments as if they were a path that can be wandered off from. Alternate translation: "who go away from the path of your commandments" or "who disobey your commandments" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who wander from your commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: What a person does or how he behaves is spoken of as if it were a road or way. Alternate translation: "what I have done" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: The word "path" here refers to a way of behaving. Alternate translation: "Keep me from following the path of deceit" or "Prevent me from being deceptive" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn from me the path of deceit

contextId.occurrenceNote: How a person behaves or acts is spoken as if it were a road or way. Alternate translation: "to be faithful to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the way of faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Holding tightly to them refers to being committed to obeying them. Alternate translation: "I hold tightly to your covenant decrees" or "I am committed to obeying your covenant decrees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I cling to your covenant decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of being focused or committed to obeying God's commands as if one is running on a path. Alternate translation: "I will be committed to obey your commands" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will run in the path of your commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Guide me according to your commandments" or "Teach me to obey your commandments." God's commandments are compared to a path that a person walks in obedience to God. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Guide me in the path of your commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a metaphor that refers to one desiring things that have no eternal value. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Turn my eyes from looking at worthless things

contextId.occurrenceNote: To walk securely is to live one's life securely. Alternate translation: "I will live securely in God" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: I will walk securely

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this metaphor, wicked or evil people tried to cause the writer to sin like a hunter seeking to catch an animal with a trap. Alternate translation: "My enemies have tried to catch me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The cords of the wicked have ensnared me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People everywhere in the world being able to see evidence of Yahweh's covenant faithfulness is spoken of as if his covenant faithfulness filled the earth. The abstract noun "covenant faithfulness" can be translated as an adjective. See how you translated a similar phrase in [Psalms 33:5](../033/005.md). Alternate translation: "People everywhere on earth can see that you, Yahweh, are faithful to your covenant" or "Throughout the earth, there is evidence that you, Yahweh, are faithful to your covenant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: The earth, Yahweh, is full of your covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Disobeying God is spoken of as if the person walked on the wrong path. Alternate translation: "I disobeyed you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I went astray

contextId.occurrenceNote: People telling many lies about a person is spoken of as if they made the person dirty by spreading lies over him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: smeared me with lies

contextId.occurrenceNote: God creating a person is spoken of as if God used his hands to shape the person the way someone may shape clay into an object. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Your hands have made and fashioned me

contextId.occurrenceNote: People returning in friendship to the writer is spoken of as if they physically turn towards him. Alternate translation: "come to me" or "unite with me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turn to me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The proud are seeking to capture the writer or cause him to do wrong. This is spoken of as if they were hunters digging holes to trap the writer like an animal. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The proud have dug pits for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks about what God has said as if it were an object that stands firmly upright. Alternate translation: "what you have said will be true in heaven forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your word is established firmly in heaven

contextId.occurrenceNote: Trying hard to obey God's instructions is spoken of as if instructions were an object for which a person must search. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for I seek your instructions

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's commandments always being true and perfect is spoken of as if God's commandments were an object that is so wide that it never ends. Alternate translation: "but your commandments are without limits" or "but your commandments are eternal" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: but your commandments are broad, beyond limits

contextId.occurrenceNote: Constantly thinking about God's commandments is spoken of as if the commandments were an object that the writer keeps with him always. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your commandments are always with me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Avoiding doing what is evil is spoken of as if it were avoiding walking on paths that are evil. Alternate translation: "I have avoided doing what is evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I have kept my feet back from every evil path

contextId.occurrenceNote: Continuing to obey God's righteous decrees is spoken of as if the writer has not physically turned away from the righteous decrees. This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: "I always obey your righteous decrees" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: I have not turned aside from your righteous decrees

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer delighting in what God says is spoken of as if God's words were food that tasted sweet to the writer. Alternate translation: "Your words are good and delightful!" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: How sweet are your words to my taste, yes, sweeter than honey to my mouth!

contextId.occurrenceNote: Evil behavior is spoken of as if it were a false way or road. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: therefore I hate every false way

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his prayer as if it were a sacrifice that he is offering to God. Alternate translation: "my prayer as a sacrifice to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: freewill offerings of my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wicked people trying to capture and kill the writer is spoken of as if they were hunters setting a trap to catch an animal. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The wicked have set a snare for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not disobeying God's instructions is spoken of as if the writer has not walked away from God's instructions. This can be stated in positive form. Alternate translation: "I obey your instructions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: I have not strayed from your instructions

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer always cherishing and obeying God's decrees is spoken of as if the decrees are land or a possession that the writer will inherit. Alternate translation: "Your laws will belong to me forever" or "Your covenant decrees are like a heritage I will keep forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I claim your covenant decrees as my heritage forever

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person who is not sincere and not fully committed to obeying God is spoken of as if the person has two minds. Alternate translation: "who are not completely committed to obeying you" or "who are insincere" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who have a double mind

contextId.occurrenceNote: God making the writer safe is spoken of as if God were a place where the writer could go and hide. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my hiding place

contextId.occurrenceNote: God protecting the writer is spoken of as if God were the writer's shield. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: A person carefully obeying all of God's instructions is spoken of as if as if the instructions were leading a person and that person follows behind. Alternate translation: I carefully obey all of your instructions" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I carefully follow all your instructions

contextId.occurrenceNote: People doing what is evil is spoken of as if they are walking on the wrong path. Alternate translation: "all the bad ways some people live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: every path of falsehood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's words as if those words were fabric that is folded, and of the person who explains Yahweh's words as if they are unfolding that fabric. Alternate translation: "The explanation of your words gives light" or "When someone explains your words, they give light" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The unfolding of your words gives light

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's words giving wisdom to a person as if his words were shining a light on them. Alternate translation: "The explanation of your words gives people wisdom" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The unfolding of your words gives light

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his desire for Yahweh's commandments as if he were a dog panting for water. Alternate translation: "I earnestly long for your commandments" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I open my mouth and pant, for I long for your commandments

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh acting favorably towards him as if Yahweh's face shone a light on him. Alternate translation: "Act favorably towards your servant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Let your face shine on your servant

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his many tears as if they were streams of water. Alternate translation: "Many tears" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Streams of tears

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's commands as if they were posts set in the ground. Alternate translation: "given them for people to obey" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set them in place

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of affliction as if it were an object that people could see. Alternate translation: "Look at how much I am suffering" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Look on my affliction

contextId.occurrenceNote: God not saving a person is spoken of as if salvation were far from the person. The abstract noun "Salvation" can be stated as "save." Alternate translation: "You will certainly not save the wicked" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: Salvation is far from the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of the ability to understand as if it were a solid object. Alternate translation: "help me understand your word" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: give me understanding into your word

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of the words he says in prayer as if they were people who want to speak to a king. Alternate translation: "May you hear my prayer" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: May my plea come before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his lips as if they were a container and his praise a liquid that could be poured out. Here the word "lips" is a synecdoche which represents the whole person. Alternate translation: "I desire to praise you much" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: May my lips pour out praise

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his tongue either 1) as if it were a person or 2) as a synecdoche for his whole being. Alternate translation: "me sing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: my tongue sing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh's decrees as if they were a person who could help him. Alternate translation: "may I listen to your righteous decrees and so become wise and strong" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: may your righteous decrees help me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of God severely punishing liars as if God were shooting them with arrows. Alternate translation: "He will punish you severely, as if he were shooting you with warrior's arrows" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He will punish you with the arrows of a warrior

contextId.occurrenceNote: These two places were far away from each other. The writer is likely using the names metaphorically to represent living among cruel and barbaric people. Alternate translation: "It is as if I live in Meshech or among the tents of Kedar" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I temporarily live in Meshech; I lived previously among the tents of Kedar

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here humiliation is spoken of as if it were something that could be fill up a person. "we are very disgraced" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we are filled with humiliation

contextId.occurrenceNote: This metaphor describes how the Israelites could have died to how a fierce animal would attack a smaller animal to eat. Alternate translation: "killed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: swallowed us up alive

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water. Alternate translation: "Our enemies would have easily defeated us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The water would have swept us away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a flood of water that would have drowned the Israelites. Alternate translation: "our enemies would have overwhelmed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the torrent would have overwhelmed us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the enemies of the writer are spoken of as if they were a raging river that would have drowned the Israelites. Alternate translation: "our enemies would have destroyed us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the raging waters would have drowned us

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemies are spoken of as if they were wild animals that would destroy the Israelites by eating them. Alternate translation: "destroyed as if we were eaten by wild animals" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: torn by their teeth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes his escape from the enemies as if he was a bird that had escaped from the snare of the hunters. Alternate translation: "escaped from our enemies as a bird escapes from the trap that hunters have set" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: escaped like a bird out of the snare of the fowlers

contextId.occurrenceNote: The plot of the enemies to catch the writer failed as if it was a snare that had broken. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the snare has been broken

contextId.occurrenceNote: Refusing to obey Yahweh is spoken of as turning away from a good path. Alternate translation: "leave good and go" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: turn aside

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here wicked ways are spoken of as if they were a path that is not straight. Alternate translation: "their wicked ways" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their crooked ways

contextId.occurrenceNote: Laughing is spoken of as if their mouths were a container and their laughter was in it. It can be made clear that this laughter was a response to their joy. Alternate translation: "we laughed for joy" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: our mouths were filled with laughter

contextId.occurrenceNote: property that a person can inherit from his ancestors. Children normally receive an inheritance from their parents. Inheritance goes from parents to children. This passage uses parents inheriting children from Yahweh as a metaphor for Yahweh being the only one who can give children. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: heritage

contextId.occurrenceNote: A quiver is a container for arrows. Having many children is spoken of as if the children were arrows in a quiver. Alternate translation: "a home full of children" or "many children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his quiver full of them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The cuts from a whipping are spoken of as the plow of a plowman. A farmer plowed deep lines into a field. Alternate translation: "My enemies have cut me deeply on my back" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The plowers plowed on my back

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is a continuation of the plowing metaphor. The "furrow" is the line the farmer plowed. Alternate translation: "they made their cuts long" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: they made their furrows long

contextId.occurrenceNote: Israel is spoken of as being bound by evil people. Alternate translation: "he has freed us from our enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he has cut the ropes of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author's sadness is spoken of as if it were a container. His sadness comes from the bottom of the container. Sadness is often spoken of as being a container that fills from the top to the bottom. Alternate translation: "Because I am very sad, I" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Out of the depths I

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a man. Alternate translation: "You people of Israel, hope in Yahweh" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Israel, hope in Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The people of Israel are spoken of as if they were a man. Alternate translation: "who will redeem the people of Israel from all their sins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: who will redeem Israel from all his sins

contextId.occurrenceNote: Things that are too hard for a person to understand are spoken of as if they are beyond the person or too far away from the person to be able to reach them. Alternate translation: "things that are too hard to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: things that are beyond me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of himself being content and resting as if he were a young child that no longer demands breast milk from his mother. Alternate translation: "content like a young child that no longer cries for breast milk but rests in his mother's arms" or "content and resting" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: a weaned child with his mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: Sleep and rest are spoken of as if they are things that can be given. Here eyes and eyelids represent the whole person. Alternate translation: "I will not allow my eyes to sleep or my eyelids to rest" or "I will not sleep or close my eyes and rest" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-synecdoche]])
contextId.glQuote: I will not give sleep to my eyes or rest to my eyelids

contextId.occurrenceNote: Worshiping God at the covenant box is spoken of as bowing at the feet of the king who is sitting on his throne. This communicates humility and submission to God. Alternate translation: "we will go to God's covenant box and worship him as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: we will worship at his footstool

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place God chose for people to worship him is spoken of as if it were a place where he rests or lives eternally. Alternate translation: "the place where you stay" or "your tabernacle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your resting place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Integrity is spoken of as if it were clothing. Alternate translation: "May people recognize that your priests have integrity" or "I want people see how your priests always do what is right" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: May your priests be clothed with integrity

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "turning away" means to reject someone. Alternate translation: "do not abandon the king that you anointed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: do not turn away from your anointed king

contextId.occurrenceNote: Making a king's descendant become king in his place is spoken of as placing him on that king's throne. AT "I will cause one of your descendants to rule Israel in your place" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will place one of your descendants on your throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: Ruling as king is spoken of as sitting on the throne. Alternate translation: "rule as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: sit on your throne

contextId.occurrenceNote: The place God chose for people to worship him is spoken of as if it were a place where he rests or lives eternally. Alternate translation: "the place where I stay" or "my tabernacle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my resting place

contextId.occurrenceNote: Salvation is spoken of as if it is clothing. Possible meanings are 1) "I will cause the priests to behave in a manner worthy of ones whom I have saved" or 2) "I will save her priests" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will clothe her priests with salvation

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of a powerful descendant of David as if he was the powerful horn of an animal. Alternate translation: "I will make a descendant of David become king after him" or "I will cause David to have a descendant who will be a powerful king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will make a horn to sprout for David

contextId.occurrenceNote: God speaks of causing David's descendants to continue to rule as king as if they were a lamp that would continue to shine. Alternate translation: "I will cause my anointed one's descendants to continue to rule as king" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: set up a lamp for my anointed one

contextId.occurrenceNote: Shame is spoken of as if it was clothing. This shame would result from losing in war. Alternate translation: "I will cause his enemies to be ashamed" or "I will cause his enemies to be defeated and ashamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: I will clothe his enemies with shame

contextId.occurrenceNote: The relationships among fellow God's people is spoken of as if they were brothers. Alternate translation: "for God's people to live together peacefully as brothers" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: for brothers to live together

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I know that our Lord is above all gods." Being greater than something is spoken of as being above it. Alternate translation: "that our Lord is greater than all gods" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: that our Lord is above all gods

contextId.occurrenceNote: A storehouse is a place where things are kept for future use. This imagery shows God's power to control the wind. Alternate translation: "causing the wind to blow by his power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: bringing the wind out of his storehouse

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's gift of the land to the Israelites is spoken of as if it were inheritance from father to son. Alternate translation: "He gave us their land to have forever" or "He gave us their land to be ours forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He gave us their land as an inheritance

contextId.occurrenceNote: The sun is spoken of as if it were a king. Alternate translation: "to mark the time of day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: to rule by day

contextId.occurrenceNote: The moon, and stars are spoken of as if they were kings. Alternate translation: "to mark the time of night" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-personification]])
contextId.glQuote: to rule by night

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "hand" and "arm" represent power. Alternate translation: "with great power" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: with a strong hand and a raised arm

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here defeat is spoken of as if it were tipping someone over. Alternate translation: "defeated Pharaoh" or "defeated the king of Egypt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: overthrew Pharaoh

contextId.occurrenceNote: The condition of feeling shame is spoken of as if it were a place that the Israelites had been in. This is a reference to the many times when the Israelites' enemies had defeated them in battle and shamed them. Alternate translation: "cared when we were shamed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: helped us in our humiliation

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing people to be victorious and defeat their enemies is spoken of as giving them victory, as if victory were an object that can be given. Alternate translation: "has made us victorious over our enemies" or "has made us able to defeat our enemies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has given us victory over our enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: Jerusalem being captured by an enemy army is spoken of as if it had fallen. Who captured Jerusalem can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "the day Jerusalem was captured" or "the day the Babylonian army entered Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the day Jerusalem fell

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of someone doing to others what they have done as if were payment. Alternate translation: "does to you what you did to us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pays you back for what you have done to us

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression probably means that God is not faithful to those who are proud. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the proud he knows from far off

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being in danger is spoken of as being in a physical place. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in the middle of danger

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he will strike the enemies with his hand. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: you will reach out with your hand against the anger of my enemies

contextId.occurrenceNote: God is spoken of as if he had physically used hands to create. Alternate translation: "you have created" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: your hands have made

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "path" stands for one's behavior. "My path and my lying down" together represent everything about the psalmist. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-merism]])
contextId.glQuote: my path and my lying down

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "word on the tongue" represents speech. Alternate translation: "before I say anything" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: before there is a word on my tongue

contextId.occurrenceNote: This expression refers to guidance and help. Alternate translation: "you guide and help me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: place your hand upon me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being high and out of reach is an expression, in this case, about some knowledge that human beings cannot have. Alternate translation: "it is too difficult to understand" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it is too high, and I cannot reach it

contextId.occurrenceNote: "Making one's bed" refers to staying somewhere. Alternate translation: "even if I stay in Sheol" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: if I make my bed in Sheol

contextId.occurrenceNote: In the ancient near east, the sun was often imagined as if it had wings which enabled it to fly across the sky. Alternate translation: "If the sun could carry me with itself across the sky" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If I fly away on the wings of the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of the night as if it were a blanket that could conceal him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: If I said, "Surely the darkness will cover me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The night, which is dark, is spoken of as if it were bright with light. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: The night would shine like the day

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is probably a way of speaking about a mother's womb (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the depths of the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "way" stands for behavior. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: any wicked way

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "way" refers to trust and obedience in God. Anyone who "walks" this way will have everlasting life. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the everlasting way

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who cause conflict by what they say are spoken of as if they had tongues of serpents. Of course, snakes do not do damage with their tongues, but with their bites and especially with poison. Neither can a person make his tongue sharp. Instead, here the idea of a sharp tongue stands for speaking in a way to cause trouble. And the idea the snakes have sharp tongues stands for the fact that many of them have poison. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Their tongues wound like serpents

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, the power of the wicked (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the hands of the wicked

contextId.occurrenceNote: The exact kinds of traps are less important than the idea that wicked and proud people are planning to make trouble for the psalmist. If your readers do not know much about different ways of trapping, you may need to reduce this to one line. Alternate translation: "have set a trap to catch me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-doublet]])
contextId.glQuote: have set a trap ... have spread a net ... have set a snare

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "battle" probably stands for any kind of severe trouble (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: battle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The trouble that they themselves caused by what they said. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the mischief of their own lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: That is, stop them from causing any more trouble. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: cover them

contextId.occurrenceNote: Images of fire stand for severe punishment for the wicked. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Let burning coals fall on them; throw them into the fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if evil words were prisoners trying to escape from his mouth. Alternate translation: "please help me not to say things that are evil" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: place a guard over my mouth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if evil words were prisoners trying to escape from his mouth. Alternate translation: "please help me not to say things when I should not" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: guard the door of my lips

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks as if giving a rebuke were physically hitting someone. Alternate translation: "rebuke me" or "hit me so I will listen when he corrects me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: hit me

contextId.occurrenceNote: "I am asking you to protect me" See how "take refuge" is translated in [Psalms 118:9](../118/009.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in you I take refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of deceiving a good man so the good man will sin or so that the evil people can defeat him as if it were laying a trap for an animal. The word "snares" is a metonym for the people themselves. Alternate translation: "people who are looking for ways to harm me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: the snares that they have laid for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of telling Yahweh why he is sad as if he were pouring all of a liquid out of a container. Alternate translation: "I tell him all about why I am sad" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: pour out my lament before him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of people wanting to harm him as if they were trying to trap an animal. Alternate translation: "They are making plans so that whatever I do they can harm me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: In the way that I walk they have hidden a trap for me

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here sight represents judgment or evaluation. Alternate translation: "in your judgment no one is righteous" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: in your sight no one is righteous

contextId.occurrenceNote: Defeating an enemy is spoken of as a heavy object crushing a lighter object on the ground. Alternate translation: "has completely defeated me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: has crushed me to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of wanting to be with God as if he were in a parched land and he also was about to die of thirst. Alternate translation: "I want to be with you the way a person in a parched land who is very thirsty wants water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my soul thirsts for you in a parched land

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist desires to know Yahweh. The intensity of his desire to know Yahweh is like one who is very thirsty. Alternate translation: "I long for you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my soul thirsts for you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh refusing to do what the psalmist asks as if Yahweh were refusing to even look at the psalmist. This litotes can be stated as a positive. Alternate translation: "Do not refuse to listen to me" or "Please listen to me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-litotes]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not hide your face from me

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of the way people live as if it were a path on which they walk. Alternate translation: "how you want me to live" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the way where I should walk

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "help me to live righteously" or 2) "may my life be free of trouble" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: lead me in the land of uprightness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) this is a metaphor for righteous living or 2) "a level land," a metaphor for life free of trouble. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the land of uprightness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) "the one who keeps me safe" or 2) "the one who gives me strength" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my rock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist uses many metaphors to emphasize that Yahweh will protect him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my fortress ... take refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a fortress that protects him from attack. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my high tower

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of Yahweh as if he were a shield that protects a soldier. Yahweh is the one who protects David from harm. See how this is translated in [Psalms 18:2](../018/002.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: my shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: Going to Yahweh for protection is spoken of as taking refuge in him. Alternate translation: "the one to whom I go so he will protect me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the one in whom I take refuge

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks as if God were on land above a flood and had physical hands with which he could pull David out of a flood. The flood is a metaphor for the troubles caused by the "foreigners." Alternate translation: "You who are able to act, help me overcome my troubles" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Reach out your hand from above; rescue me out of many waters

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their right hand is falsehood

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are 1) David speaks of the custom of raising the right hand to swear that what one is about to say in court is true, "they lie even when they swear to tell the truth," or 2) the "right hand" is a metaphor for power, "everything they have gotten, they have gotten by telling lies."See how you translated these words [Psalms 144:8](./008.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: their right hand is falsehood

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of covenant faithfulness as if it were a physical object of which one could possess a large amount. The abstract noun "faithfulness" can be translated with an adjective. Alternate translation: "completely faithful to his covenant" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: abounding in covenant faithfulness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of Yahweh encouraging people as if he were helping people who were physically weak. You may need to translate both lines using only one line. AT "encourages those who are discouraged" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: supports all who are falling ... raises up all those who are bent over

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "is near" means "ready to help." Alternate translation: "is always ready to help all those who call to him" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: is near to all those who call to him

contextId.occurrenceNote: Causing a blind person to see is spoken of as if Yahweh were opening the person's eyes. Alternate translation: "causes the blind to see" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: opens the eyes of the blind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh helping someone is spoken of as if he were physically helping someone to stand up. Alternate translation: "Yahweh helps those who are discouraged" or "Yahweh helps those who are weak" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh raises up those who are bowed down

contextId.occurrenceNote: God helping someone is spoken of as if he were physically lifting them up. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he lifts up

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the people's sorrow and discouragement as if they were physical wounds, and of Yahweh encouraging them as if he were healing those wounds. Alternate translation: "He encourages those who are sad and helps them to heal from their emotional wounds" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: He heals the brokenhearted and binds up their wounds

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh honoring those who are oppressed as if Yahweh were lifting them up from the ground. Alternate translation: "Yahweh honors the oppressed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh lifts up the oppressed

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh humiliating the wicked as if Yahweh were forcing them to lie on the ground. Alternate translation: "he humiliates the wicked" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he brings the wicked down to the ground

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of those who live in Jerusalem as if they were Jerusalem's children. Alternate translation: "he blesses those who live in Jerusalem" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: he blesses ... among you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's command as if it were his messenger. The word "command" can be translated with a verb. Alternate translation: "He commands the ice to melt" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-abstractnouns]])
contextId.glQuote: He sends out his command and melts them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's greatness as his glory being high above earth and heaven. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: his glory extends over the earth and the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of strength as if it were the horn of an animal. Lifting up an animal horn was a symbolic action that represented military victory. Alternate translation: "He has made his people strong" or "He has given his people victory" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/translate-symaction]])
contextId.glQuote: He has lifted up the horn of his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh loving his people as if his people were physically close to him. Alternate translation: "the people he loves" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: the people near to him
